node.title: SA records six COVID-linked deaths and 1,505 new cases
node.alt: A man wearing a suit with another man wearing a suit and a face mask behind him
node.description: Six COVID-related deaths have been reported in South Australia in the past 24 hours,Â taking the total since the start of the pandemic to 117.
node.content:
["Six COVID-related deaths have been reported in South Australia in the past 24 hours.", "There have been 1,505 positive cases recorded during the same period.", "There are 281 people in hospital \u2013 a drop of eight from yesterday.", "There are still 25 people in intensive care and the number of people on ventilators has doubled to four.", "\"I've got to begin by sadly acknowledging the passing of six South Australians reported over the past 24 hours,\" Premier Steven Marshall said.", "\"That takes our total in this state since the pandemic began in early 2020 to 117.\"", "Mr Marshall said\u00a02,227 people have recovered from the virus in the past day, bringing the total number of active cases to fewer than 20,000 \u2014 a\u00a0\"massive fall of where we were two or three weeks ago\".", "\"We currently have 19,847 active cases so we've broken through that 20,000-active cases barrier, going in the right direction this time,\" he said.", "\"We now have more than 1,000 members of the Aboriginal community in South Australia who are COVID-positive.", "\"The vast majority of those people are living [at] home. I think we have 29 people who are currently in hospital and three who are in ICU.\"", "The number of SA Health staff furloughed stands at 371, including 241 who are COVID-positive.", "School today resumed for the children of essential workers and those from vulnerable backgrounds, ahead of the start of the term proper on Wednesday.", "Some year levels will return to face-to-face learning, while others will persist with remote learning until they too are allowed back into\u00a0classrooms on February 14.", "The government today released further details of online learning options.", "Education Minister John Gardner said the Our Learning SA website would enable lessons to be delivered to students at home, saying electronic devices had been made available to those in need.", "\"Our schools have had, over the last two years, policies in place to ensure that those families and children who needed a device to be able to access learning were able to access those,\" he said.", "\"Many of those were school devices.\"", "More to come.", "", "
I've had COVID, can I get it again?
"]
